subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Unicode proposal again.
msgSnippet: Ah, oops - I didn t mean to respond privately, I guess I hit the wrong button. :) I d be happy to re-post that message to the Unicode list if you like. Okay,
messageBody:
Ah, oops - I didn't mean to respond privately, I guess I hit the wrong
button. :)
I'd be happy to re-post that message to the Unicode list if you like.

Okay, as I see it the following glyphs are the same in Quikscript and
Shavian:

DAY == DEAD
KEY == KICK
FEE == THIGH (different sound)
SEE == SO
ZOO == ZOO
SHE == SURE
CHEER == CHURCH
JAY == JUDGE
WAY == WOE
ING == HUNG (different sound?)
ROE == ROAR
IT == IF
ET == EGG
AT == ASH
AH == MIME (different sound)
AWE == NUN (different sound)
OX == ON
UTTER == ADO and LOLL (different sound)
OWE == OAK

Please double check that list though - I have been hitting the wrong
buttons a lot today. :)

There are 13 glyphs/sounds pairs which match up (I'm not certain on
ING/HUNG).
Since code points are allocated in 16s we would still use the same space
but we would have more unused code points.
That would leave room for additions, but Quikscript is quite well
defined are we going to need them?

Michael Everson wrote:
>
> Peter asked this on the Unicode forum, and I responded:
>
> One question that needs to be addressed (and has since I asked this a
> year or so ago) is
> whether it an be unified with Shavian.
>
> Peter responded to me privately:
>
> "Looking at it there are only a few glyphs with the same shape in
> Shavian and they have
> totally different meanings so I don't think they can be unified."
>
> This needs substantiation.
>
> I love encoding. I'm a splitter, normally, not a lumper. But if I'm
> not convinced about
> disunifying Quikscript from the Shavian it derives from, the UTC and
> WG2 certainly won't be.
>
> This discussion begins, alas, just as I am about to go on a
> fortnight's holiday. My e-mail
> access will be spotty from tomorrow until 14 June. But tonight (as I'm
> all packed but for my
> computer) I'll look into this.
>
>
